abstract.t: Routers could have neighbors who are stuck on their input queue. This document updates RFC 4271.

section.title: Introduction
section.t:
Since the BGP Protocol runs over TCP it is possible for hosts in ESTABLISHED state to encounter a peer that is advertising a zero windows size and preventing KEEPALIVE, CEASE, WITHDRAW, UPDATE and other critical messages from being sent.
Since implementaions themselvs do not have a way to handle this, this often results in a soft Denial Of Service either to handling messages or delivering reachablity information to other peers.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

section.title: Updates to RFC 4271
section.t: Few words need to be changed in .
OLD: 6.5. Hold Timer Expired Error Handling

If a system does not receive successive KEEPALIVE, UPDATE, and/or NOTIFICATION messages within the period specified in the Hold Time field of the OPEN message, then the NOTIFICATION message with the Hold Timer Expired Error Code is sent and the BGP connection is closed.
NEW: 6.5. Hold Timer Expired Error Handling

If a system does not send and receive successive KEEPALIVE, UPDATE, and/or NOTIFICATION messages within the period specified in the Hold Time field of the open message, then the BGP connection is closed and a log message is emitted.
